comments.body: this needs a link to our recommendation. I would suggest minikube onboarding and docker-env.

[According to Dan Lorenc](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/kubernetes-sig-cluster-lifecycle/XFODRr_TXgE/hmJ_5v5LCgAJ), minikube is targeting k8s end users. Using it for development of Kubernetes may be [not very convenient](https://github.com/kubernetes/minikube/blob/master/UPDATE_KUBERNETES.md). Or did I miss something here? Also, minikube by itself is probably overkill if the developer just wants to have docker.

+1 for Ivan, minikube is _not_ for developers of k8s, for developers of k8s look at https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/36590#issuecomment-259802736 or https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/36590#issuecomment-259808686
For local docker, pretty much any recent version works.  I used 1.9 until recently.

Sure "but pretty much any recent version" is not sufficient and I would really just like us to punt to somewhere where we know a known good version is being maintained. For cross-platform availability for workstations the closest thing we got is minikube.

@ivan4th @pigmej Also, it isn't for k8s developer but it is a known good version of the Docker engine that the k8s community tests and packages as VMs.

@@ -1,1 +108,112 @@   should work.
1. `docker` - some parts of the build/test system depend on `docker`.  You
   need a relatively recent version of Docker installed, and available to you.
1. `go` - Kubernetes is written in Go (aka golang), so you need a relatively
   recent version of the [Go toolchain](https://golang.org/dl/) installed.

@@ -1,1 +13,17 @@
If you have a question about Kubernetes or have a problem using it, please
start with the [troubleshooting guide](docs/troubleshooting.md).  If that

issue](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/new).

comments.body: We use the phrase `PR` many places. Could/should we say `... to send a Pull Request (PR).` So they can some context for the acronym in later reading?

I did notice the use of "PR" in several of the other documents that I read. My argument is that being new to Kubernetes development, I would much rather reserve every bit of mental energy to understanding the code-base, not deciphering/intuiting unnecessary abbreviations. 

I'll do the grunt-work of reviewing the documentation and replacing every single instance of PR with Pull Request, making minor copy edits as I go along and send another _Pull Request_.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +5,9 @@## Developer Guide

We have a [Developer's Guide](docs/devel/README.md) that outlines everything you need to know from setting up your dev environment to how to get faster Pull Request reviews. If you find something undocumented or incorrect along the way, please feel free to send a Pull Request.
